question: Pollination can be divided into ______ types depending on the source of pollen.
In autogamy, pollination is achieved within the ______ flower.
Transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of the ______ flower is autogamy.
A normal flower opens and exposes the anthers and the ______.
Complete autogamy in normal flowers is rather ______.
Autogamy requires synchrony in pollen release and ______ receptivity.
In autogamy, anthers and stigma should lie close to each other for ______ to occur.
Viola, Oxalis, and Commelina produce two types of flowers â€“ chasmogamous and ______.
Chasmogamous flowers have exposed anthers and ______.
Cleistogamous flowers do not ______ at all.
In cleistogamous flowers, the anthers and stigma lie ______ to each other.
When anthers dehisce in flower buds, pollen grains contact the ______ to effect pollination.
Cleistogamous flowers are invariably ______.
Cleistogamous flowers produce assured seed-set even in the absence of ______.
Geitonogamy is transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of another flower of the ______ plant.
Geitonogamy is functionally ______ involving a pollinating agent.
Genetically, geitonogamy is similar to ______.
Xenogamy is transfer of pollen grains from anther to the stigma of a ______ plant.
Xenogamy is the only type of pollination bringing genetically ______ pollen grains to the stigma.
Plants use two abiotic agents, wind and ______, for pollination.
Plants use one biotic agent, ______, for pollination.
Majority of plants use ______ agents for pollination.
Only a small proportion of plants use ______ agents.
Pollen grains coming in contact with the stigma is a ______ factor in both wind and water pollination.
Flowers produce enormous amount of pollen to compensate for loss of pollen and associated ______.
The number of ovules available for pollination is ______ compared to pollen production.
